Kamal,

 

Yes.

 

First, start here:

 

http://tech.groups.yahoo.com/group/junit/message/17529

 

Above and beyond this, my advice is to write two layers of tests--one 

for the user, and one for the developer. 

 

The user tests should be plug-in tests that come as close as possible to 

simulating user actions and testing UI appearance, down to simulating 

mouse clicks (I've recently written a framework that makes this much 

easier, but it's not clear yet whether it will be released.  Working on 

such a thing on your own, if you get time and permission, can teach you 

a lot about how Eclipse is built).

 

The developer tests should be vanilla JUnit tests, which don't require 

any of the Eclipse runtime to be in place.  In some places, Eclipse 

helps with this: many interesting operations are defined and invoked on 

interfaces that you can mock.  In some places, Eclipse gets in your 

way.  One example is that SWT is difficult to load at runtime without 

the whole Eclipse runtime coming along for the ride.  However, there's a 

tip in the e-mail above that will get around that.

 

Worse is that Eclipse often gets the implementors of those nice 

interfaces by making direct static calls to unmockable runtime classes.  

This will push your design in a certain direction--you will need to wrap 

these global services and override or mock them in your tests.  If your 

team is test-infected, then this shouldn't be a problem.  If not, there 

may be some grumbling about making your design more complicated "just 

for testing".  However, point out to them the ability gained to run 

100's of tests in under 5 seconds, compared to the 30 seconds it usually 

takes just to boot the Eclipse runtime, and the even longer time it 

takes to test manually.  Also, I find that the design pressures of 

wrapping the Eclipse services leads me to some nice model classes that 

are comprehensible even to people who know nothing about Eclipse, 

allowing me to leverage a much broader range of design advice and 

implementation expertise.

 

If you have more questions, please post them here; I find this to be a 

really fun problem to work on.  Thanks,

 

    David Saff
